sourcesContent:
import { Component } from "react";
import "./index.css";
import DiseasesItems from "./DiseasesItems";
import DiseasesCard from "./Diseases-card";

const diseasesList = [
  {
    id: 1,
    name: "White Spot Syndrome (WSS)",
    diseaseImg:
      "https://res.cloudinary.com/dpvrtbqxt/image/upload/v1739731676/DALL_E_2025-02-17_00.17.10_-_A_detailed_digital_illustration_of_a_prawn_infected_with_White_Spot_Syndrome_WSS_shown_in_a_wider_view._The_prawn_has_a_translucent_reddish-brown_e_n7twkk.webp",
  },
  {
    id: 2,
    name: "Yellow Head Disease (YHD)",
    diseaseImg:
      "https://res.cloudinary.com/dpvrtbqxt/image/upload/v1739731909/DALL_E_2025-02-17_00.21.33_-_A_detailed_digital_illustration_of_a_prawn_infected_with_Yellow_Head_Disease_YHD_shown_in_a_slightly_zoomed-out_view._The_prawn_has_a_swollen_yell_lcfvrj.webp",
  },
  {
    id: 3,
    name: "Vibriosis",
    diseaseImg:
      "https://i.pinimg.com/736x/93/12/60/931260aa76f5ef8af9a2173b4298ffb1.jpg",
  },
  {
    id: 4,
    name: "Black Gill Disease",
    diseaseImg:
      "https://res.cloudinary.com/dpvrtbqxt/image/upload/v1739731283/DALL_E_2025-02-17_00.10.54_-_A_highly_detailed_close-up_digital_illustration_of_a_prawn_infected_with_Black_Gill_Disease._The_prawn_has_a_reddish-brown_exoskeleton_with_darkened_audt4e.webp",
  },
  {
    id: 5,
    name: "Taura Syndrome",
    diseaseImg:
      "https://i.pinimg.com/736x/93/12/60/931260aa76f5ef8af9a2173b4298ffb1.jpg",
  },
  {
    id: 6,
    name: "Infectious Hypodermal and Hematopoietic Necrosis (IHHN)",
    diseaseImg:
      "https://i.pinimg.com/736x/93/12/60/931260aa76f5ef8af9a2173b4298ffb1.jpg",
  },
];

const iniatialisedDiseasesCardList = [
  {
    id: 1,
    heading: "White Spot Disease (WSD)",
    description:
      "White Spot Disease (WSD) is one of the most devastating viral diseases affecting shrimp, caused by the White Spot Syndrome Virus (WSSV). This highly contagious virus spreads rapidly in shrimp farms through contaminated water, infected shrimp, equipment, and carrier species like crabs and wild crustaceans.The disease is characterized by the appearance of white, calcium-like spots on the exoskeleton of infected shrimp, lethargy, loss of appetite, and high mortality within a few days of infection. WSD outbreaks are often triggered by sudden temperature fluctuations, poor water quality, overcrowding, and stress.WSD can cause mass mortality in shrimp farms within 3 to 10 days, leading to severe economic losses. Since there is no specific cure for WSD, farmers must focus on prevention through biosecurity measures, disease-resistant shrimp strains, and maintaining optimal environmental conditions. Early detection and immediate action, such as isolating infected shrimp, can help control the spread of the disease.",
    treatment:
      "There is no effective treatment for White Spot Disease, making prevention and management essential. Farmers should implement strict biosecurity measures to prevent the virus from entering their farms. Using specific pathogen-free (SPF) shrimp and disinfecting all equipment and water sources can significantly reduce the risk of infection.Maintaining stable water quality is crucial to preventing stress-induced outbreaks. Regular monitoring of water temperature, pH, salinity, and dissolved oxygen levels can help create a healthy environment that reduces shrimp susceptibility to infections. Sudden environmental changes should be avoided, as they can weaken shrimp immunity and increase the risk of WSD.Infected shrimp should be removed immediately to prevent the spread of the virus. Draining and disinfecting affected ponds before restocking is essential to eliminate any viral particles. Using probiotics and immune-boosting feed additives can help enhance shrimp resistance to infections.Some studies suggest that natural antiviral agents, such as seaweed extracts and immunostimulants, may help strengthen shrimp defenses against WSSV. However, these methods should be used as preventive measures rather than treatments. Regular health checks and early detection through PCR testing can help farmers take immediate action to minimize losses.",
    tips: [
      "Use SPF shrimp and disinfect all farm equipment regularly.",
      "Maintain stable water temperature and avoid sudden environmental changes.",
      "Remove infected shrimp immediately and disinfect affected ponds.",
      "Conduct routine health monitoring and use immune-boosting feed.",
    ],
    Symptoms: [
      "White spots (1–2 mm) on the exoskeleton.",
      "Lethargy and weak swimming behavior.",
      "Reduced feeding or complete loss of appetite.",
      "High mortality within 3–10 days of infection.",
      "Soft shell and molting problems.",
      "Reddish body coloration in severe cases.",
      "Shrimp swimming near the water surface.",
      "Sudden population die-offs.",
    ],
  },
  {
    id: 2,
    heading: "Yellow Head Disease (YHD)",
    description:
      "Yellow Head Disease (YHD) is a highly infectious viral disease caused by the *Yellow Head Virus* (YHV), which affects *Penaeus monodon*, *Penaeus vannamei*, and other shrimp species. The disease was first identified in Thailand and has since spread to several shrimp-producing regions worldwide.YHD primarily targets the shrimp’s hepatopancreas and gill tissues, leading to rapid mortality in infected populations. The disease gets its name from the characteristic yellowish discoloration of the shrimp’s cephalothorax. Infected shrimp also exhibit erratic swimming behavior, loss of appetite, and swelling of the hepatopancreas.Transmission occurs through direct contact with infected shrimp, contaminated water, and carrier species such as crabs. Environmental stress, overcrowding, and poor pond management can increase the risk of outbreaks. Since YHD spreads quickly and causes mass mortality within 3 to 5 days, early detection and immediate biosecurity measures are crucial for preventing farm losses.",
    treatment:
      "There is no specific treatment for Yellow Head Disease, so prevention is the best strategy. Farmers should implement strict biosecurity measures to prevent the virus from entering their farms. Using specific pathogen-free (SPF) shrimp stocks and disinfecting all water sources, equipment, and farm structures can significantly reduce the risk of infection.Water quality management is critical for preventing stress-induced outbreaks. Maintaining optimal levels of pH, temperature, salinity, and dissolved oxygen helps create a stable environment that reduces shrimp susceptibility to YHV. Sudden environmental changes should be avoided, as they can weaken shrimp immunity and increase the risk of infections.Infected shrimp should be removed and properly disposed of to prevent the spread of the virus. Farms experiencing YHD outbreaks should drain and disinfect affected ponds before restocking. Using probiotics and immune-boosting feed can help enhance shrimp resistance to viral infections.Selective breeding programs have developed shrimp strains that are more resistant to YHV. Implementing regular health monitoring and PCR testing for early detection can help farmers take immediate action to prevent losses. Strengthening shrimp immunity with vitamins, minerals, and herbal extracts may also help in disease prevention.",
    tips: [
      "Use SPF shrimp and maintain strict biosecurity measures.",
      "Keep water quality stable and avoid sudden environmental changes.",
      "Remove infected shrimp immediately and disinfect affected ponds.",
      "Enhance shrimp immunity with high-quality feed and probiotics.",
    ],
    Symptoms: [
      "Yellowish or pale discoloration of the head.",
      "Swelling of the cephalothorax (head region).",
      "Reduced feeding and sluggish behavior.",
      "Soft shell and molting problems.",
      "Rapid mortality, sometimes within 24 hours.",
      "Shrimp floating near the water surface.",
      "Mass die-offs in ponds.",
      "Internal organs appear pale and degenerated.",
    ],
  },
  {
    id: 3,
    heading: "Vibriosis",
    description:
      "Vibriosis is a bacterial disease in shrimp caused by *Vibrio* species, including *Vibrio harveyi*, *Vibrio parahaemolyticus*, and *Vibrio vulnificus*. These bacteria are naturally present in marine environments but can become pathogenic when shrimp are stressed due to poor water quality, overcrowding, or sudden environmental changes. The disease can manifest in various forms, including shell disease, tail rot, and septicemia. Infected shrimp may show symptoms such as reddish discoloration, blackened or eroded shells, loss of appetite, lethargy, and high mortality rates. In severe cases, internal organ failure occurs, leading to sudden die-offs. Vibriosis is particularly dangerous in shrimp hatcheries and farms with poor management practices. It can spread through contaminated water, infected shrimp, and biofilm formation in farm equipment. Farmers must focus on maintaining optimal water conditions and improving shrimp immunity to prevent outbreaks.",
    treatment:
      "Vibriosis can be managed with antibiotics, but their use should be regulated to prevent antibiotic resistance. Instead, farmers should prioritize natural treatments and preventive measures. Probiotics are highly effective in controlling Vibrio populations in shrimp ponds. These beneficial bacteria compete with pathogenic Vibrio species, reducing their growth and impact. Maintaining proper water quality is crucial. Regular monitoring of ammonia, nitrite, and pH levels can prevent stress-induced infections. Proper aeration and regular water exchange help keep bacterial populations in check. Shrimp farms should implement biosecurity measures, such as disinfecting equipment and using pathogen-free shrimp stocks. Any dead or infected shrimp should be removed immediately to prevent further bacterial spread. Natural treatments, such as garlic extract, turmeric, and essential oils, have shown promise in controlling Vibrio infections in shrimp. These natural antimicrobials help boost shrimp immunity and reduce bacterial loads. Additionally, using immunostimulants such as beta-glucans and vitamin C can enhance shrimp resistance against infections. A balanced diet with high-quality feed helps strengthen shrimp immunity. Farmers should avoid overfeeding, as excess organic matter can promote bacterial growth. Proper pond sediment management and regular cleaning of biofilms in water systems can further reduce the risk of Vibrio outbreaks.",
    tips: [
      "Use probiotics to control Vibrio populations and improve shrimp health.",
      "Maintain good water quality and avoid overfeeding.",
      "Remove dead shrimp immediately to prevent bacterial spread.",
      "Strengthen shrimp immunity with vitamins, garlic extract, and natural antimicrobials.",
    ],
    Symptoms: [
      "Lethargy and reduced activity.",
      "Loss of appetite and weak feeding behavior.",
      "Reddening of the body and tail.",
      "Soft shell and poor molting.",
      "Lesions or ulcers on the shell.",
      "Swollen hepatopancreas (digestive organ).",
      "Cloudy or darkened gills.",
      "High mortality if untreated.",
    ],
  },
  {
    id: 4,
    heading: "Black Gill Disease",
    description:
      "Black Gill Disease is a condition in shrimp that results in darkened or blackened gills due to infections, poor water quality, or parasitic infestations. The disease is not caused by a single pathogen but can be triggered by bacterial, fungal, or protozoan infections, as well as environmental stressors such as high ammonia levels, low dissolved oxygen, and heavy metal contamination. The disease affects the shrimp’s gills, reducing their ability to extract oxygen from the water, leading to respiratory distress, reduced growth, and increased mortality. Affected shrimp often become lethargic, weak, and may float near the water surface due to oxygen deprivation. In severe cases, Black Gill Disease can cause mass mortality in shrimp farms. Since the disease can be caused by multiple factors, proper pond management, good aeration, and maintaining optimal water conditions are critical for prevention. Early detection and prompt corrective measures, such as improving water quality and using probiotics, can help mitigate the impact of the disease.",
    treatment:
      "Black Gill Disease requires a multi-faceted approach for effective management, as it can be caused by bacterial, fungal, or parasitic infections. The first step in treatment is identifying and addressing the underlying cause of the disease. Improving water quality is crucial to preventing and managing Black Gill Disease. Farmers should regularly monitor water parameters such as ammonia, nitrite, and dissolved oxygen levels. Regular water exchange, proper aeration, and maintaining a balanced pH can help reduce environmental stressors that contribute to the disease. If the disease is caused by bacterial infections, administering probiotics and antibacterial treatments through feed can help reduce bacterial load. In cases where fungi or protozoa are the culprits, applying antifungal or antiparasitic treatments may be necessary. However, any chemical treatments should be used with caution to avoid harming beneficial microorganisms in the pond. Shrimp farmers should also ensure proper stocking densities to minimize stress and disease transmission. Regular sediment removal and pond bottom cleaning can help prevent the accumulation of harmful bacteria and parasites. Strengthening shrimp immunity through high-quality feed, vitamins, and probiotics can also help prevent infections. Farmers should conduct routine health checks and remove severely infected shrimp to prevent the disease from spreading. Implementing a strict biosecurity plan and avoiding the use of contaminated water sources can significantly reduce the risk of outbreaks.",
    tips: [
      "Maintain optimal water quality by monitoring ammonia and oxygen levels.",
      "Use probiotics and immune-boosting feed to strengthen shrimp resistance.",
      "Remove infected shrimp immediately to prevent the spread of disease.",
      "Avoid overstocking and ensure proper aeration in shrimp ponds.",
    ],
    Symptoms: [
      "Dark or blackened gills.",
      "Reduced oxygen intake.",
      "Lethargy and weak swimming behavior.",
      "Slow or reduced feeding.",
      "Shell discoloration in severe cases.",
      "Gills clogged with organic matter.",
      "Increased vulnerability to secondary infections.",
      "High mortality in extreme cases.",
    ],
  },
  {
    id: 5,
    heading: "Taura Syndrome (TSV)",
    description:
      "Taura Syndrome Virus (TSV) is a highly contagious viral disease affecting shrimp, particularly *Penaeus vannamei*. It was first discovered in Ecuador in the early 1990s and has since spread to shrimp farms worldwide. TSV primarily spreads through contaminated water, infected shrimp, and predator species such as birds and crabs. Environmental factors like poor water quality, overcrowding, and temperature fluctuations increase the risk of outbreaks. The disease has three phases: 1. **Acute Phase:** Shrimp develop soft shells, reddish discoloration, and erratic swimming behavior. Mortality is highest at this stage. 2. **Transition Phase:** Some shrimp start to recover, but dark melanized spots may form on their shells. 3. **Chronic Phase:** Infected shrimp appear normal but remain carriers of the virus, posing a long-term risk to farm populations. TSV is one of the most economically damaging diseases in shrimp farming due to its rapid spread and high mortality rates. Prevention through biosecurity and resistant shrimp strains is crucial for controlling outbreaks.",
    treatment:
      "There is no specific antiviral treatment for Taura Syndrome, so prevention and management are the primary methods of controlling the disease. The best approach is strict biosecurity to prevent the introduction of TSV into shrimp farms. Farmers should only stock shrimp from TSV-free hatcheries and avoid introducing wild crustaceans, which can be carriers of the virus. Water quality plays a crucial role in preventing stress-induced infections. Shrimp ponds should be well-aerated, and ammonia, nitrite, and pH levels should be regularly monitored to ensure a stable environment. Keeping water temperatures consistent reduces stress on shrimp and lowers the risk of infection. Selective breeding programs have developed TSV-resistant shrimp strains, which offer a long-term solution for affected farms. Using probiotics and immune-boosting feed additives can help strengthen shrimp immunity and reduce susceptibility to infections. Infected shrimp should be removed from the pond immediately to prevent the virus from spreading further. Equipment, tools, and farm workers’ hands should be properly disinfected. Any new shrimp introduced to the farm should undergo a quarantine period to ensure they are disease-free before being placed in the main culture ponds.",
    tips: [
      "Use only certified TSV-free shrimp stock.",
      "Maintain stable water quality and avoid sudden temperature fluctuations.",
      "Remove infected shrimp immediately to reduce the risk of further spread.",
      "Implement strict biosecurity and regular pond disinfection practices.",
    ],
    Symptoms: [
      "Reddish coloration on the body and tail.",
      "Soft shell and weak exoskeleton.",
      "Lethargy and reduced movement.",
      "Lethargy and reduced movement.",
      "Blackened gills in later stages.",
      "Sudden high mortality in juvenile shrimp.",
      "Molting issues leading to deformities.",
      "Small melanized (black) spots on the shell.",
    ],
  },
  {
    id: 6,
    heading: "Infectious Hypodermal and Hematopoietic Necrosis (IHHN)",
    description:
      "Infectious Hypodermal and Hematopoietic Necrosis (IHHN) is a viral disease affecting shrimp, particularly *Penaeus vannamei* and *Penaeus stylirostris*. It is caused by the IHHN virus, which primarily affects the exoskeleton and hematopoietic tissues, leading to deformities, reduced growth, and high mortality in juvenile shrimp. The disease is transmitted through infected shrimp, contaminated water, and carrier species such as crabs. IHHN often causes runt deformity syndrome (RDS), where infected shrimp exhibit bent or deformed rostrums and uneven growth rates. Severe infections lead to high mortality, particularly in *P. stylirostris*, while *P. vannamei* usually survives but suffers from reduced growth and productivity. The disease is widespread in shrimp farms globally and can cause significant economic losses due to poor shrimp quality and lower market value. Since there is no cure for IHHN, strict biosecurity measures and using virus-free shrimp stocks are the best strategies for controlling outbreaks.",
    treatment:
      "There is no direct treatment for IHHN, so prevention through strict biosecurity is the best approach. Farmers should use specific pathogen-free (SPF) shrimp stock to reduce the risk of disease outbreaks. All new shrimp should be quarantined before being introduced to culture ponds. Maintaining optimal water quality is essential to reduce stress and enhance shrimp immunity. Regular monitoring of parameters such as pH, dissolved oxygen, and ammonia levels helps create a stable environment that lowers the risk of infections. Proper pond management, including regular water exchange and sediment removal, also reduces the chances of viral persistence. Infected shrimp should be removed and properly disposed of to prevent further transmission. Equipment, feed trays, and worker clothing should be disinfected regularly to minimize contamination risks. The use of probiotics and immune-boosting feed additives can help shrimp develop stronger resistance to infections. Selective breeding programs have developed IHHN-tolerant shrimp strains, which can be a long-term solution for affected farms. Farmers should also avoid co-culturing shrimp with wild crustaceans, as they can be carriers of the virus. Regular disease screening and monitoring of shrimp health can help detect early signs of infection and prevent large-scale losses. ",
    tips: [
      " Use only specific pathogen-free (SPF) shrimp stock. ",
      "Maintain optimal water quality and stable pond conditions.",
      "Regularly disinfect equipment and remove infected shrimp.",
      "Avoid co-culturing shrimp with wild crustaceans to reduce transmission risks.",
    ],
    Symptoms: [
      "Deformities in the shell and rostrum.",
      "Slow growth and stunted development.",
      "Soft shell and weak exoskeleton.",
      "Reduced activity and lethargy.",
      "Molting problems.",
      "High mortality in juvenile shrimp.",
      "Blackened or darkened tissues.",
      "Surviving shrimp may carry the virus without symptoms.",
    ],
  },
];

class Disease extends Component {
  state = { isClicked: false, diseasesCardList: "" };

  viewDetails = (id) => {
    const filteredData = iniatialisedDiseasesCardList.filter(
      (each) => each.id === id
    );
    this.setState({ isClicked: true, diseasesCardList: filteredData });
  };

  backToDiseasesPage = () => {
    this.setState({ isClicked: false });
  };

  render() {
    const { isClicked, diseasesCardList } = this.state;
    return (
      <div className="disease-container">
        {isClicked ? (
          <DiseasesCard
            key={diseasesCardList.id}
            cardDetails={diseasesCardList[0]}
            backToDiseasesPage={this.backToDiseasesPage}
          />
        ) : (
          <div>
            <h1 className="Disease-heading">Diseases:</h1>
            <ul className="card-container">
              {diseasesList.map((each) => (
                <DiseasesItems
                  key={each.id}
                  diseaseList={each}
                  viewDetails={this.viewDetails}
                />
              ))}
            </ul>
          </div>
        )}
      </div>
    );
  }
}

export default Disease;
